solutions.title: ruby-working-with-priority-queue-in-ruby-one-approach
solutions.content:
### Note about Priority Queues in Ruby

There are no built in Priority Queue in Ruby. If you need one can use initialy sorted array and use method `Array#bsearch_index` to find element.

### Optimization

Change odd numbers to even initially to have one type of tranformation -- divide any even number by two.

### Algorithm

Divide maximum number by two while its even each time check for `max - min` diff. When maximum is odd we stop: cannot decrease max num.

### Implementation

Store numbers in Priority Queue - sorted array. Pop max number, divide by two, put back in priority queue.
Here used helper method to put an element in ASC sorted array (sort of a min-heap), but we `pop` element from the end of an array.

```ruby
# Insert value into ASC sorted array (min-heap). Change to `y <= x` for max-heap.
def heappush(arr, x)
  idx = arr.bsearch_index { |y| y >= x } || arr.size
  arr.insert(idx, x)
end

def minimum_deviation(nums)
  (0...nums.size).each { |i| nums[i] *= 2 if nums[i].odd? }
  nums.sort!
  res = nums.last - nums.first

  while (mx = nums.pop).even?
    heappush(nums, mx / 2)
    res = [res, nums.last - nums.first].min
  end
  res
end
```

### Same with sort of a max-heap

Now sort array nums in descending order.
Change `y => x` to `y <= x`, `nums.pop` to `nums.shift` and `nums.last - nums.first` to `nums.first - nums.last`

```ruby
# Insert value into DESC sorted array (sort of a max-heap)
def heappush(arr, x)
  idx = arr.bsearch_index { |y| y <= x } || arr.size
  arr.insert(idx, x)
end

def minimum_deviation(nums)
  (0...nums.size).each { |i| nums[i] *= 2 if nums[i].odd? }
  nums.sort_by!(&:-@) # Same as `nums.sort!.reverse!`
  res = nums.first - nums.last

  while (mx = nums.shift).even?
    heappush(nums, mx / 2)
    res = [res, nums.first - nums.last].min
  end
  res
end
```

NOTE: this version gives TLE. Apparenlty `Array#pop` is faster then `Array#shift`

### One general approach (variant) to work with Priority Queue in Ruby

Two handy helper methods to work with ascending sorted array (sort of a min-heap)

```ruby
# Insert element into ASC sorted array.
def heappush(arr, x)
  idx = arr.bsearch_index { |y| (y <=> x) >= 0 } || arr.size
  arr.insert(idx, x)
end
# Remove element from ASC sorted array if the element is present.
def heappop(arr, x)
  idx = arr.bsearch_index { |y| (y <=> x) >= 0 }
  arr.delete_at(idx) if idx && arr[idx] == x
end
```

Same for descending sorted array

```ruby
# Insert element into DESC sorted array.
def heappush(arr, x)
  idx = arr.bsearch_index { |y| (y <=> x) <= 0 } || arr.size
  arr.insert(idx, x)
end
# Remove element from DESC sorted array if the element is present.
def heappop(arr, x)
  idx = arr.bsearch_index { |y| (y <=> x) <= 0 }
  arr.delete_at(idx) if idx && arr[idx] == x
end
```

### UPDATE: Another solution without Heap

Storing extracted maximums divided by 2 in another array `q`.

```ruby
def minimum_deviation(nums)
  nums.each_with_index {|x, i| nums[i] *= 2 if x.odd? }
  nums.sort!
  res = nums.last - nums.first
  q = []

  while [nums.last, q.first].compact.max&.even?
    if nums.any? && (q.empty? || q.first < nums.last)
      m = nums.pop
    else
      m = q.shift
    end
    q << m/2
    res = [res, [nums.last, q.first].compact.max - [nums.first, q.last].compact.min].min
  end
  res
end
```

Time complexity: `O(n * log n)`

solutions.content:
**Algo** 
Convert all numbers to even. Then, we don't have to worry about 2nd operation entirely. Maintain a max heap and progressively divide the largest number by 2 until one cannot. The minimum deviation generation in this process is the required answer. 

**Implementation**
```
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        pq = [-2*x if x&1 else -x for x in nums]
        heapify(pq)
        most = max(pq)
        ans = most - pq[0]
        while not pq[0]&1: 
            x = heappop(pq)//2
            heappush(pq, x)
            most = max(most, x)
            ans = min(ans, most - pq[0])
        return ans 
```

**Analysis**
Time complexity `O(NlogN)`
Space complexity `O(N)`

solutions.content:
You can use multiset also. Works same
Intuition : 

### **Keep the array sorted, in the left half, greedily make all the odd numbers into even numbers by multiplying them by 2, in the right half, greedily try to make all the even numbers as half of it so that on the left side you increase the low and on the right side you increase the high.**
## 

# **** APPROACH****

First, try to make all of the odd as even, we are doing this as we are processing the odd numbers first by making them even as we are allowed to make them even, so we are making them believing in the fact that, if needed, once again we can make them odd by dividing them again by 2. so we are not at loss, if initially we make all the odd even.

This is where your intuition will develop.
Now try to keep the array sorted, for that we will use RED BLACK TREES (SET) in order to maintain the array sorted,
we will first insert all the elements into the set, after that, if we see in set, we have some odd number, we remove that and insert 2 times its value i.e. an even number in the set. The set has a beutiful property that it will keep it sorted and no repeat numbers will be there.
You can use multiset if you dont want to keep same elements. (WONT MAKE A DIFFERENCE)

Then what you do, you try to reduce the upper limit as initially by inserting the 2*odd you already attempted for increasing the lower limit of your set. 
Now keep on reducing the rightmost element of your set till it becoms odd. and try to do that again and again.

At one time, you will see that the last or rightmost element of your set is indeed odd.
You will stop there.

At every point of your while loop you will keep on updating the min deviation of your set, that would be the difference of your last and first element of your set.

IT WOULD BE MORE CLEAR WITH THESE PICTURES


![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/addc3962-f8a3-4095-bd1d-745a7fe0095d_1645270871.523419.png)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/911fda92-1abd-4380-8771-67e726306566_1645270881.9688013.png)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/4f3ec741-4e39-4684-9002-a60337b95b7f_1645270892.1677568.png)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/d8896dee-3dda-470a-a0e0-545e6c3f75e6_1645270900.8156424.png)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/f11074bc-8bc5-4f27-ad93-65ff075cc7a3_1645270910.574225.png)



CODE:
```
class Solution {
public:
    int minimumDeviation(vector<int>& nums) {   
        set<int> s;
        for(auto i: nums) s.insert(i); //insert everything into a set
        int dev= *s.rbegin()-*s.begin(); //difference between max and min
        for(auto i: nums) if(i&1){ s.erase(i);s.insert(i<<=1);} //remove all odds, add 2*odd
        while(!((*s.rbegin())&1)){ //while last element does not become odd
            int a=(*s.rbegin());
            s.erase(a); //remove last
            s.insert(a>>=1); //insert last/2
            dev=min(dev,*s.rbegin()-*s.begin()); //update min deviation
        }
        return dev;
    }
};

```

python-cleanest-solution-sorted-list
solutions.content:
The easiest way to solve this problem is to convert all numbers to even numbers and add them to a sorted container. Then just keep on reducing the maximum difference between them.

There are two ways to reduce their distance:
1. Keep increasing smallest number (multiplying by 2)
2. Keep decreasing largest number (divide by 2)

In this solution we pick approach 2, as it is easier to implement and comes more naturally due to the boundary conditions. So we just minimise the difference and update the maximum number by dividing it with 2 for every iteration. We use a sorted list to maintain the sorted order so that we can get the minimum and maximum easily in each iteration.
```
Sorted container = [min, ... other elements..., max]
```
We keep on doing this until we can, i.e until the max element can be halved (note: only an even number can be halved without losing precision if we want to keep only the integer part).

Python Code Below:
(Please do upvote)

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        sl = SortedList([i*2 if i%2==1 else i for i in nums])
        diff = float('inf')
        while sl[-1] % 2 == 0:
            diff = min(diff, sl[-1]-sl[0])
            sl.add(sl.pop(-1) // 2)
        return min(diff, sl[-1]-sl[0])
```
solutions.code:
```
Sorted container = [min, ... other elements..., max]
```
```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        sl = SortedList([i*2 if i%2==1 else i for i in nums])
        diff = float('inf')
        while sl[-1] % 2 == 0:
            diff = min(diff, sl[-1]-sl[0])
            sl.add(sl.pop(-1) // 2)
        return min(diff, sl[-1]-sl[0])
```

solutions.content:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/53584f09-ffd2-4806-b234-4e2c9eec1c99_1677197885.228521.png)
```
def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            nums[i] = -((nums[i] << 1) if nums[i] & 1 == 1 else nums[i])

        min_num = -max(nums)
        max_nums = nums
        heapq.heapify(max_nums)

        min_deviation = math.inf
        while True:
            max_num = -max_nums[0]
            deviation = max_num - min_num

            if deviation < min_deviation:
                min_deviation = deviation
                if min_deviation == 0:
                    break

            if max_num & 1 == 1:
                break

            max_num >>= 1
            heapq.heapreplace(max_nums, -max_num)
            if max_num < min_num:
                min_num = max_num

        return min_deviation
```

Here is a step-by-step explanation of the code:
1. The input array is modified to turn every odd number negative and double its value. This is done by iterating over every element of the input array, checking if it's odd or even, and applying the appropriate operation using bitwise operators. This is done so that we can perform only the "divide by 2" operation in the following steps, which simplifies the problem.
1. The maximum number in the modified array is assigned to a variable named "minNum". This is because we want to minimize the deviation of the array, and having a larger minimum number in the array would increase the deviation.
1. A heap is created from the modified array. The heap is used to keep track of the maximum value in the array, which we can modify by dividing it by 2.
1. A variable named "minDeviation" is initialized to infinity. This variable will be used to keep track of the minimum deviation we have encountered so far.
1. We enter a while loop that will terminate only when we have found the minimum deviation or when we can no longer perform any operations.
1. The maximum value in the heap is extracted and assigned to a variable named "maxNum".
1. The deviation of the array is calculated as the difference between the maximum value (after dividing by 2 if it's even) and the minimum value.
1. If the deviation is less than the minimum deviation seen so far, it is updated as the new minimum deviation.
1. If the maximum value is odd, we can no longer perform any operations and we break out of the while loop.
1. If the maximum value is even, we divide it by 2 and replace the maximum value in the heap with the new value.
1. If the new maximum value is less than the current minimum value, we update the minimum value to be the new maximum value.
1. The loop continues until we have found the minimum deviation or can no longer perform any operations.
1. The minimum deviation is returned as the final result.

solutions.content:
### **Idea**
Observe that we can *only* increase value (by x2) for odd numbers. That means for an odd number like `3`, possible values we can reach are `{3, 6}`; and for an even number like 8, possible values we can reach are `{1, 2, 4, 8}`. We can unify both cases by starting from the largest reachable value (`6` and `8`) and only consider the "//2" (divide by 2) operation.

Since now numbers can only decrease, the *only* sensible move is to take the largest number and half it. Otherwise, we face the risk of lower the minimum without lowering the maximum. 

What data structure should we use? Halving the largest number will surely lower the maximum but would also create a new minimum. So we would like something that would efficiently keep track of both the max and min values. If you browse other posts, you will see people use a binary search tree for this, but a *heap / priority queue* that only tracks the max value will also suffice for this problem.

This is because, in each step, we a new minimum is only possible from halving the current maximum (heap top). So we can keep a variable `mi` for this and update it along with each operation. 

### **Optimazations / implementation choices**
- We only need to consider unique values from the input as diverging from the same starting values won't make a solution any better. (`heap = list(set(...))`)
- Negate the values to have a max heap.
- For the current max value, we can just take `heap[0]`.
- The process ends when it is impossible to reduce the max value, i.e. `heap[0] % 2 == 0` does not hold.

### **Code**
```python
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        heap = list(set(-(x * 2 if x & 1 else x) for x in nums))
        heapify(heap)
        ma, mi = -heap[0], -max(heap)
        ans = ma - mi
        while heap[0] % 2 == 0:
            x = heappop(heap) // 2
            heappush(heap, x)
            ma, mi = -heap[0], min(mi, -x)
            ans = min(ans, ma - mi)
        return ans
```

### **Complexity**
- O(n) space. The heap contains all the input elements when they are all unique.
- O(n (log m) (log n)) time, where `m = max(nums)`. The heap is O(n) size, so it takes O(log n) time for each push and pop. How many steps do we need to take? That is how many times we can reduce the max value, which is again bounded by the number of reachable values for each input element. The max number of reachable values is for some 2^k that is as big as the limit for input values m. The reachable values for it will be 1, 2, ..., 2^(k-1), 2^k --- (log m) of them. Thus, we will need to do O(n log m) steps in the worst case.

### **Further optimizations**
I personally think the following optimizations hurt readability a bit, so I didn't include them in the primary solution. None of them affects the big-O notation complexity, but they can save us some time that hides as "negligible factors".
- Have signs reversed during the computation and only correct it before returning the `ans`. This makes it cleaner with less `-` (negation) and presumably saves computation.
- Reuse `ma` for `heap[0]` look-ups.
- This one probably saves the most computation time: use `heapq.heapreplace()` ([python doc](https://docs.python.org/3/library/heapq.html#heapq.heapreplace)) instad of `heappop()` followed by `heappush()`. [This stackoverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/46031391) explains a bit more why `heapreplace()` can be more efficient.

### **Code 2**
```python
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        heap = list(set(-(x * 2 if x & 1 else x) for x in nums))
        heapify(heap)
        ma, mi = heap[0], max(heap)
        ans = ma - mi
        while ma % 2 == 0:
            x = ma // 2
            heapreplace(heap, x)
            ma, mi = heap[0], max(mi, x)
            ans = max(ans, ma - mi)
        return -ans
```

### **Submission stats**
Runtime: 836 ms (beats 99.15%)
Memory Usage: 30.7 MB (beats 30.77%)

---
If you find this helpful, please **upvote**! It will greatly encourage me to write more like this in the future. Thank you! 🤗

solutions.content:
I saw a lot of solutions using min-heap and for that you need to first factor a = 2ⁿ  * k where k is an odd number. However if you use max-heap and *only* go downward (in an ideal world where every given number is even, we only need to divide by 2), such a factorization is not necessary. 

So how do you arrive at the ideal world? 
**Observation**: the answer won't change if an odd number `k` is replaced by `2k`. (because `2k` can only be changed to `k` and vice versa.) So that's it. 

```
    def minimumDeviation(self, A: List[int]) -> int:
        A = [-a * (1 + a%2) for a in A] # multiply odd number by 2. negative sign is only for max heap.
        m = -max(A)                     # min of the new list.
        heapq.heapify(A)                # now it's a heap in the "ideal world".
        res = math.inf
        while True:
            a = -heapq.heappop(A)
            res = min(res, a-m)
            if a & 1: 
                return res
            a >>= 1
            m = min(m, a)
            heapq.heappush(A, -a)
```

short-python-greedy
solutions.content:
We first multiply our odd elements by two and sort the new array. So now we are left with one operation, dividing even number by two. Record current deviation `nums[-1] - nums[0]`, then keep dividing maximal number by two and update the min deviation with the new difference `nums[-1] - nums[0]` in new nums array. At some moment you will stop, thus return the min deviation you was tracking.

With this greedy algorithm all possible maximal right ends will be visited, and the left end for it will be minimal possible. Therefore, greedy will work correctly. Short python code below:

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums):
        def even(k):
            return 2 * k if k % 2 == 1 else k
        nums = SortedList([even(k) for k in nums])
        minn = nums[-1] - nums[0]
        while nums[-1] % 2 == 0:
            nums.add(nums[-1] // 2)
            nums.pop(-1)
            minn = min(minn, nums[-1] - nums[0])
        return minn
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
1. Notice that an odd number, say `k`, can only be reduced to `k` or `k * 2`

2. Let's start off with `nums` where all odd numbers are reduced to even by multiplying with `2`.
    This essentially eliminates `rule of odds`, as all numbers are `even`.
    Note that this doesn't affect the answer.

3. The `min_deviation` right now is `max_value - min_value`.

3. Take the largest number, say `m`, and apply the `even rule`, i.e `m // 2`. Update the `min_deviation` if it's decreased.

4. Now do the same with the current largest number.

5. Keep doing this until the largest number `m` is not `even` anymore.

6. To repeatedly fetch the largest number, modify it, put it back in sorted order. We can either use a `Heap / PriorityQueue` or `OrderedSet / SortedList`. Both solutions are shown below.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n * log(m * n))$$

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$

where,
`n is number of elements in nums`,
`m is the maximum value element in nums`.

# Code
Heap / PriorityQueue solution:
```python
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: list[int]) -> int:
        hq = [-n * 2 if n % 2 else -n for n in nums]
        heapify(hq)

        min_ = -min(hq, key=neg)
        min_deviation = -hq[0] - min_

        while hq and hq[0] % 2 == 0:
            n = heappop(hq) // 2
            heappush(hq, n)
            min_ = min(min_, -n)
            min_deviation = min(min_deviation, - hq[0] - min_)
        
        return min_deviation


```
OrderedSet / SortedList solution:
```python
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: list[int]) -> int:
        sl = SortedList(n * 2 if n % 2 else n for n in nums)

        min_deviation = sl[-1] - sl[0]
        while sl[-1] % 2 == 0:
            sl.add(sl.pop() // 2)
            min_deviation = min(min_deviation, sl[-1] - sl[0])
        return min_deviation


```

solutions.content:
1. Create a max heap(negative min heap) of nums with maximum possible values.
2. In a loop, Keep track of minimum deviation:
a. Pick the max(top) element from heap. Divide it by 2. If it's greater than min, reduce it to lowest number greater than min.
b. Terminate the loop when the top element is odd,

Time: Beats 97%, Memorry: Beats 34%

```
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        heap = [-n*2  if n%2 else -n for n in set(nums)]
        heapify(heap)

        min_n, max_n = -max(heap), -heap[0]
        min_dev = max_n - min_n

        while max_n % 2 == 0:
            new_n = max_n // 2
            while new_n&1 == 0 and new_n>>1 > min_n:
                new_n >>= 1

            heapreplace(heap, -new_n)
            min_n, max_n = min(new_n, min_n), -heap[0]
            min_dev = min(max_n - min_n, min_dev)
        return min_dev
```

```
from heapq import heappush, heappop, heapify


class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        # convert all numbers to even and put into max heap
        pq = [-x * 2 if x % 2 == 1 else -x for x in nums]
        heapify(pq)  # now pq is max heap (with negative values)

        min_n = -max(pq)  # negative max is min of original values
        dev = -pq[0] - min_n # current deviation is max - min

        # while we can still divide the max element by 2
        while pq[0] % 2 == 0:
            x = heappop(pq)  # take the max value
            half_x = x // 2  # divide by 2
            heappush(pq, half_x)  # put it back
            min_n = min(min_n, -half_x)  # update min
            dev = min(dev, -pq[0] - min_n) 

        return dev
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Intuition is...Think that what will give you the best answer if you converted all your array element to even or odd.
So, if I converted all my array element to odd and sort it then calculate the deviation (max element,min element ) then it will give you the answer but not always right because you have to minimise you deviation.So we can convert all our array element to even.
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
We have to convert our odd array element to even so that whole array become even and then sort the array.Deviation is (Max element - Min element) so store that difference to any variable(res) and then you need to minimize that deviation but do not forget the condition of Deviation(max element - min element).So for minimization you can do another operation (maximum element)/2 and put that element to your array and delete the maximum element from the array.Then again sort the updated array and minimize you difference. Do the same process until your largest element is even and then break the loop because if your largest element is odd then you cannot do any further operations to minimize your ans. 

Here instead of array you can use extra space O(n) priority queue or SortedSet so that it will sort automatically.

In my solution I am using sortedSet(In scala Set will not sort automaticaly you need to use SortedSet.)


# Complexity
- Time complexity:O(nlogn)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:O(n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
import scala.collection.mutable.SortedSet
object Solution {
    def minimumDeviation(nums: Array[Int]): Int = {
        //Creation of Sortedset
        var s:SortedSet[Int]=SortedSet()
        for(i<-nums)
        yield
            if (i%2==1) //converting all odd elemnt to even
                s+=i*2      //storing elements to Set
            else s+=i

        var res=s.last-s.head; //Max deviation Calculation
        while(s.last%2==0)   //until you largest element is even
        {
            
            s+=s.last/2       //even element by 2 to reduse the answer
            s-=s.last          //deletion largest element 
            res=Math.min(res,s.last-s.head) //Minimizing the difference
            // println(s)

        }
        return res; //required answer


    }
}
```

# **PLEASE UPVOTE :)**
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        heap=[]
        mx=[]
        for i in nums:
            if i&1:
                # heapq.heappush(heap,i*2)
                heapq.heappush(mx,-i*2)
            else:
                # heapq.heappush(heap,i)
                heapq.heappush(mx,-i)
        # print(mx)
        mnn=-max(mx)
        diff=float('inf')
        while(len(nums)==len(mx)):
            # mn=heapq.heappop(heap)
            mxx=-heapq.heappop(mx)
            diff=min(diff,mxx-mnn)
            if mxx%2==0:
                mnn=min(mxx//2,mnn)
                heapq.heappush(mx,-mxx//2)
            else:
                break
            # print(mx,diff,mnn)
        return diff

```

solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
###### Create a `Max_Heap` having maximum possible value for each element. Repeatedly pop the `top` (max element) of the heap and divide it by 2 until the `top` of the heap is even and update the minimum deviation for each step.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(nlogn)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        maxHeap = [-x*2 if x % 2 != 0 else -x for x in nums]
        heapify(maxHeap)
        ans, minItem = maxsize, -max(maxHeap)
        while maxHeap[0] % 2 == 0:
            maxItem = -heappop(maxHeap)
            ans = min(ans, maxItem - minItem)
            maxItem //= 2
            minItem = min(minItem, maxItem)
            heappush(maxHeap, -maxItem)
        ans = min(ans, -maxHeap[0] - minItem)
        return ans
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
We will use priority heap.

1. Multiply all odd numbers by 2 => we get maximum possible values of all numbers in nums. Now all numbers are even.

2. We will use priotrity heap. But we need multiply all numbers by (-1), because we will take maximum element of heap, not minimum.

3. Keep track min number in heap. Don't forget to multiply it by (-1).

4. Take max number from heap(remember about (-1)). While it is even, divide it by 2 and put it back to heap. Since max number is odd we stop.

5. Keep the min difference between max number and min number as a result. And update min number every step.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n logn)$$
- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$

# Code
```
from heapq import heappop, heappush


class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        result = float('inf')
        heap = []  
        for n in set(nums):
            if n % 2 == 0:
                heappush(heap, (-1) * n)
            else:
                heappush(heap, (-2) * n)
        heap_min = (-1) * max(heap)
        while heap[0] % 2 == 0:
            heap_max = (-1) * heappop(heap)
            heappush(heap, (-1) * heap_max // 2)
            result = min(result, heap_max - heap_min)
            heap_min = min(heap_min, heap_max // 2)
        heap_max = (-1) * heappop(heap)
        result = min(result, heap_max - heap_min)
        return result
        
```

            heap_max = (-1) * heappop(heap)
            heappush(heap, (-1) * heap_max // 2)

        return result
        
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
Initially push event elements in the heap (maxHeap).
While doing so if odd element is found double it and insert.
Now maintain currMin and currMax and after each iteration 
ans = min(ans, currMax-currMin).

Pop top element from the heap and that will be currMax, check for ans
push the element by dividing it by 2.
If currMax is odd stop the loop as we are treating this element again that means we are in cycle and we will get same elements again.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        heap = []
        ans = max(nums)+1
        
        for num in nums:
            if num % 2 == 0:
                heappush(heap, -num)
            else:
                # push only even values
                heappush(heap, -num*2)
        currMax = 2
        currMin = -max(heap)

        # currMax % 2. == 0 indicates we are doing only first operation on the element
        # on second operation it will be cyclic
        while currMax % 2 == 0:
            currMax = -heappop(heap)
            ans = min(ans, currMax-currMin)
            heappush(heap, -currMax//2)
            currMin = min(currMin, currMax//2)

        return ans
```

```

solutions.content:
# Approach
1. Go thru `nums` to double odd values & remove duplicates. Sort it in decreasing order.
2. Set variable `dev` as the difference between the first & last elements in `nums`.
3. While `nums[0]` contains an even value:
    1. Divide `nums[0]` by 2. If needed, move the element so that `nums` remains sorted.
    2. Set `dev` to the new difference between first & last `nums` if it is lower.
4. Return `dev`.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(nlogn)
- Space complexity: O(1), beats 100%

# Code
```
const minimumDeviation = nums => {
    nums.forEach( (n,i) => n%2 && ( nums[i] *= 2 ) )
    nums = [ ...new Set(nums) ].sort( (n,m) => m-n )
    let l = nums.length-1, dev = nums[0]-nums[l], i
    while ( nums[0]%2 == 0 ) {
        if ( (nums[0] /= 2) < nums[1] )
            i = nums.findIndex( n => n < nums[0] ),
            nums.splice( i<0 ? l : i-1 , 0, nums.shift() )
        dev = Math.min( dev, nums[0]-nums[l] )
    }
    return dev
}

```

solutions.content:
**🔼 IF YOU FIND THIS POST HELPFUL PLEASE UPVOTE 👍**

**Solution:**
```
class Solution:
    def minimumDeviation(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        # initialize a heap data structure to store the transformed values of the array elements
        heap = []
        
        for num in nums:
            # transform the number to an odd number if it is odd
            transformed_num = num
            while transformed_num % 2 == 0:
                transformed_num //= 2
            # append the tuple (transformed number, maximum limit) to the heap
            heap.append((transformed_num, max(num, transformed_num*2)))
        
        # find the maximum value in the heap
        max_num = max(i for i,j in heap)
        
        # convert the list to a heap data structure
        heapify(heap)
        
        # initialize the minimum deviation to be a large value
        min_deviation = float("inf")

        # loop until all the elements in the heap have been processed
        while len(heap) == len(nums):
            
            # pop the smallest element from the heap
            num, limit = heappop(heap)
            
            # update the minimum deviation
            min_deviation = min(min_deviation, max_num - num)
            
            # if the popped element can be doubled and still be within its limit, then push it back to the heap with the doubled value
            if num < limit:
                heappush(heap, (num*2, limit))
                max_num = max(max_num, num*2)
            
        # return the minimum deviation
        return min_deviation
```
**For Detailed Explaination Read this Blog:**
https://www.python-techs.com/2023/02/minimum-deviation-of-array-leetcode.html

**Thank you for reading! 😄 Comment if you have any questions or feedback.**

Am I the only one who gets annoyed by the way how some problems are changing definitions of the mathematical terms? \uD83E\uDD14\n\nThe maximum difference between any two elements is called **range**, deviation is a completely different thing \uD83D\uDE48

Agree. 
And also, it has a bad effect. If you didn't know the meaning before now you think you know, what does it mean but it's wrong.

Approach for this Problem:

Create a max heap and a variable to keep track of the minimum value in the array.
For each number in the input array, if it is odd, multiply it by 2 and push it onto the heap. Otherwise, just push it onto the heap.
Also, update the minimum value if necessary.
Initialize a variable to keep track of the minimum deviation.
While the maximum value in the heap is even, pop it off the heap, divide it by 2, and push it back onto the heap. Update the minimum deviation and the minimum value if necessary.
If the maximum value in the heap is odd, we cannot reduce it any further by dividing by 2. In this case, break out of the loop.
Return the minimum deviation.

Hope it helps🌝

[@dsacj](/dsacj) 
but we then get all possible max values and start to decrease them, while hint says to get all possible min values and increase them.

still, I think I kind of start to understand why upproach with min values could work...

[@KhacLong](/KhacLong) Since we want to minimize the deviation, it makes sense to try to reduce the difference between the maximum and minimum values as much as possible. Multiplying an odd number by 2 makes it even, which allows us to further reduce the maximum value of the array by dividing it by 2 in the subsequent steps.\nSo, by multiplying odd elements by 2, we are effectively reducing the maximum value of the array, which in turn reduces the deviation.

Here is the Approach:-

We create a max heap using PriorityQueue with the reverse order comparator. We do this because we want to always process the largest element in the heap first.

We iterate over the input array and for each element, we check if it is even or odd. If it is odd, we multiply it by 2 so that we can apply the second operation (multiply by 2) on it later. We add the modified element to the heap and keep track of the minimum value we encounter.

We initialize the minimum deviation variable to be the maximum integer value. We then keep looping until the largest element in the heap is odd. In each iteration, we remove the largest element from the heap and divide it by 2. We compute the new deviation between the minimum and maximum elements and update the minimum deviation variable if necessary. We also keep track of the new minimum value we encounter.

Once we have a maximum odd element in the heap, we compute the deviation between the minimum and maximum elements and update the minimum deviation variable if necessary. We return the minimum deviation variable as the answer.

3. since every element is as maximum as possible , you can not increase any number further

Here is the Approach:-

We create a max heap using PriorityQueue with the reverse order comparator. We do this because we want to always process the largest element in the heap first.

We iterate over the input array and for each element, we check if it is even or odd. If it is odd, we multiply it by 2 so that we can apply the second operation (multiply by 2) on it later. We add the modified element to the heap and keep track of the minimum value we encounter.

We initialize the minimum deviation variable to be the maximum integer value. We then keep looping until the largest element in the heap is odd. In each iteration, we remove the largest element from the heap and divide it by 2. We compute the new deviation between the minimum and maximum elements and update the minimum deviation variable if necessary. We also keep track of the new minimum value we encounter.

Once we have a maximum odd element in the heap, we compute the deviation between the minimum and maximum elements and update the minimum deviation variable if necessary. We return the minimum deviation variable as the answer.

The intuition behind this logic is to reduce the maximum difference between any two elements in the array by either decreasing the maximum value or increasing the minimum value.

By transforming all odd numbers to even numbers, we can always divide even numbers by 2, so the maximum value in the array can be reduced to its minimum possible value. We also keep track of the minimum value in the array, since we can only increase it by multiplying it by 2.

We then repeatedly pop the maximum value from the priority queue, which guarantees that we are always reducing the maximum value in the array. If the maximum value is odd, we can no longer divide it by 2, so we break out of the loop. Otherwise, we divide the maximum value by 2, which reduces the maximum value, and update the minimum value accordingly.

By doing this repeatedly, we can always reduce the maximum difference between any two elements in the array, and we keep track of the minimum deviation that we can achieve.

First understand the question, then go straight to the solution section to see how to implement!! Just kidding.

```
The goal is to close the gap between the minimum and maximum bounds of nums. 
You can multiply an odd number by 2 to increase, or divide an even number by 2 for to decrease. 
What we need is to converge all the numbers to _the smallest possible interval_, and returning this value.
```

``` Heap[]
# Heap and priority queue:
1. Initialize a heap from the given nums by multiplying all odd numbers by 2 and keeping the even integers.
 Arrange the heap in such a way that we can track on the largest value (negative order). 

2. Track the minimum and maximum value of the newly created PQ queue.
For the initial value, maxN= -queue[0], minN=min(queue), mindeviation=maxN-minN

3. Iteration: 
Divide the largest number until the largest number is odd (cannot be divided anymore), then break the loop.
Update min if maxN/2<minN
Update minimum gap: mindeviation=maxN-minN every loop.

 4. Return mindeviation.

Improvement: using set for repeat numbers in the initialization priority queue (1st step).
```



Good luck.

Otherwise, we divide the maximum value by 2, which reduces the maximum value, and update the minimum value accordingly.

By doing this repeatedly, we can always reduce the maximum difference between any two elements in the array, and we keep track of the minimum deviation that we can achieve.

spoiler alert, I didn\'t understand the given hints at all, but the one hint that immediately enabled me to find a solution was the realization that if needed, we can always divide a number back to its original value after we double it at first. Sadly I didn\'t come up with it myself despite it being quite obvious.

First understand the question, then go straight to the solution section to see how to implement!! Just kidding.

```
The goal is to close the gap between the minimum and maximum bounds of nums. 
You can multiply an odd number by 2 to increase, or divide an even number by 2 for to decrease. 
What we need is to converge all the numbers to _the smallest possible interval_, and returning this value.
```

``` Heap[]
# Heap and priority queue:
1. Initialize a heap from the given nums by multiplying all odd numbers by 2 and keeping the even integers.
 Arrange the heap in such a way that we can track on the largest value (negative order). 

2. Track the minimum and maximum value of the newly created PQ queue.
For the initial value, maxN= -queue[0], minN=min(queue), mindeviation=maxN-minN

3. Iteration: 
Divide the largest number until the largest number is odd (cannot be divided anymore), then break the loop.
Update min if maxN/2<minN
Update minimum gap: mindeviation=maxN-minN every loop.

 4. Return mindeviation.

Improvement: using set for repeat numbers in the initialization priority queue (1st step).
```



Good luck.

Why is every solution multiplying the odd number first? What if the odd number is the maximum and by multiplying it, we are increasing the deviation. It is not really an intuitive first step.

The idea is to perform only one type of operation while searching for the solution. Hence we either need to start with all possible max values and then decrease them step by step while updating the answer or we need to start with all possible min values and then increase them step by step while updating the answer.

Since it is easy to understand when we have to stop decreasing (when number is odd we can't divide it anymore and need to break out of the cycle), a lot of people suggest to start with all possible max values. For that we need to multiply odd values.

For the case when odd value is the max, let's consider this example:
[2,4,5]
- first we change it to [2,4,10]
- then we take out max value (10), calculate current answer (10 - 2 = 8). The value is even, so we can divide value by 2 and put it back - [2,4,5]
- then we take out max value (5), calculate new current answer (min(8, 5 - 2) = 3). The value is odd, so we can't divide it by 2 and cycle stops here
- then we return  3

Case 2:
In this case, if [10,4,3]  [5,4,6], then the minimum deviation should also be 6-4 = 2, not 1.
Why is every solution multiplying the odd number first? What if the odd number is the maximum and by multiplying it, we are increasing the deviation. It is not really an intuitive first step.

The idea is to perform only one type of operation while searching for the solution. Hence we either need to start with all possible max values and then decrease them step by step while updating the answer or we need to start with all possible min values and then increase them step by step while updating the answer.

Since it is easy to understand when we have to stop decreasing (when number is odd we can't divide it anymore and need to break out of the cycle), a lot of people suggest to start with all possible max values. For that we need to multiply odd values.

For the case when odd value is the max, let's consider this example:
[2,4,5]
- first we change it to [2,4,10]
- then we take out max value (10), calculate current answer (10 - 2 = 8). The value is even, so we can divide value by 2 and put it back - [2,4,5]
- then we take out max value (5), calculate new current answer (min(8, 5 - 2) = 3). The value is odd, so we can't divide it by 2 and cycle stops here
- then we return  3
